awd_titl_txt: Geomagnetic Signals from the Earth's Core: Searching for Evidence of Waves and Stable Stratification
awd_abstract_narration:
Fluctuations in the Earth's magnetic field provide unique insights into the internal dynamics of our planet. Turbulent flow in the liquid metal core generates the geomagnetic field, causing observable fluctuations at the Earth's surface.  Historical observations reveal several distinct periodicities in the range of several decades. The origin of these fluctuations is not well understood, but their existence profoundly affects our ability to forecast changes in the geomagnetic field. The proposed research seeks to develop physical models for waves at the top of the Earth's liquid core with the goal of explaining the observed geomagnetic fluctuations. Physical conditions in the core, including the possibility of density stratification, can be recovered by fitting the model predictions to the observations. One potential outcome of this project is a change in the way we interpret geomagnetic fluctuations because the presence of certain types of waves can substantially alter our understanding of dynamics near the top of the core. This work is particularly timely given a new satellite mission (ESA's Swarm mission) to monitor the Earth's magnetic field with unprecedented resolution. The combination of better observations and more realistic physical models should improve our ability to forecast of changes in the geomagnetic field over the next few decades. More broadly, our work addresses the thermal and chemical evolution of the Earth because the gradual transfer of heat and matter in the interior ultimately sets the density stratification in the present-day Earth.  

Waves with periods of several decades can arise when the top of the liquid core is stratified by either thermal or compositional gradients. These waves are sometimes called MAC waves because they involve the interplay of Magnetic, Archimedes and Coriolis forces. Preliminary results show that a linear combination of MAC provides a good description of zonal flow in the core, based on several independent estimates of core flow. The same combination of waves can also account for observed fluctuations in the dipole field. Success in explaining these distinct phenomena motivates our hypothesis that the dominant periodicities in the historical record are due to MAC waves. We explore this hypothesis by developing a more sophisticated numerical model for the wave motion and by devising more comprehensive tests using a wide range of observations, including geomagnetic secular variation and changes in the length of day. We propose to invert these observations for the structure and properties of a stratified layer in the core. We will also explore the consequences of stratification on the long-term dynamics of the core using a new geodynamo model called Calypso, which was developed at UC Berkeley with prior NSF support.  Calypso will be used to quantitatively assess the excitation of MAC waves in the core and to identify specific diagnostics that could support or refute our hypothesis.

por.por_cntn:
Fluctuations in the geomagnetic field offer a wealth of information about the internal dynamics of our planet. We used recent observations of the geomagnetic field to identify two types of waves in the Earth's core. The first is a zonal wave that is comprised of mainly east-west fluid motion. These waves have periods of several decades and are associated with distinctive fluctuations in the dipole component of the geomagnetic field. The second class of wave is trapped in the equatorial region and has a period of 6 to 8 years.  Both of these waves depend on the presence of stable stratification at the top of the core. Estimates of the strength of stratification are inferred from the propagation speed and spatial structure of these waves. This information provides constraints on the thermal and composition state of the core.  We infer the presence of a layer of thermal stratification in the top 140 km of the core. This layer suppresses convection and allows the development of a thinner layer of compositional stratification due to the process of barodiffusion (i.e. chemical diffusion due to pressure gradients). The thickness of the thinner, chemically stratified layer is roughly 30 km; it could develop over a time interval of roughly one hundred million years, which would coincide with the initial development of thermal stratification.

We also addressed the question of how these waves are excited. Convection and magnetic-field generation in the region below the stratified layer can generate waves through a variety of mechanisms. These mechanisms can include the influence of buoyant fluid rising into the stratified layer or through electromagnetic effects associated with magnetic-field generation. We use numerical geodynamo models and physical scaling to show that the influence of magnetic stresses in the core are the most likely source for the waves. The amplitude of the waves constrains on the magnitude of the generation mechanism and offers a valuable insights into the nature of convection in the core.

The presence of stratification at the top of the core challenges conventional interpretations of magnetic-field variations. Previous studies that recover estimates of fluid flow at the top of the core often find evidence for horizontal convergence of fluid motion at some locations on the core-mantle boundary. When horizontal flow converges on a particular location, there must be a radial motion away from the boundary to conserve mass. Some researchers have argued that this radial motion argues against the presence of stable stratification because this layer is expected to suppress radial motion. However, we find that horizontal flow over topography on the core-mantle boundary can produce horizontal convergence with an amplitude consistent with that inferred in previous studies. We find that boundary topography of a few hundred meters is sufficient to explain the horizontal convergence. In fact, the horizontal convergence may provide a useful constraint on the amplitude of boundary topography after establishing the strength of the stratification from the identification of waves. Because this topography is mainly due to dynamics in the mantle, we may derive unexpected insights into mantle convection and plate tectonics.
